title: 113_hr2145
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk as follows:

"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." Congress finds that since 1935, the United States has owned a 9.5-acre parcel of land in Riverside, California, administered by the Department of Agriculture for research and plant materials purposes. Since 1998, the property has been under the administration of the Natural Resources Conservation Service and co-managed since 2002 with the Riverside Corona Resource Conservation District. The Conservation District in California aims to acquire a 9.5-acre property for conservation, environmental, and educational purposes, promoting conservation education and saving costs for the Federal Government. Land conveyance of Natural Resources Conservation Service property in Riverside County, California. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey a 9.5-acre property in Riverside, California to the Riverside Corona Resource Conservation District. The District will pay the Secretary an amount equal to the property's value in use. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey a 9.5-acre property in Riverside, California to the Riverside Corona Resource Conservation District. The District will pay an amount equal to the property's value in use, with reductions for improvements provided by non-Federal sources and rental rate abatements. The consideration received will be credited to the Natural Resources Conservation Service for conservation operations in California. The Secretary will not reserve any future interest in the property to be conveyed, except as acceptable to the Conservation District. In the conveyance of the property, the Secretary is only required to disclose hazardous substances, pollutants, or contaminants, without the obligation to remediate or abate any releases. The Secretary may enter into leases, contracts, and cooperative agreements with the Conservation District for real property on a noncompetitive basis. This authority is in addition to any other authority of the Secretary. The Secretary may require reasonable terms and conditions in connection with the conveyance. The Secretary may impose reasonable terms and conditions for conveyance to protect US interests, without needing further analysis.
